results.title: Thunderbirds. Volume 1
results.creator_credit: Alan Pattillo, David Elliot, David Lane, Desmond Saunders, Gerry Anderson, APF Television Production and Associated Television
results.brief_description: 1960s British animated television series set in 2065, about a family and their associates combating various dangers with a mix of technology and intelligence. Using marionettes, “Thunderbirds” made impressive use of supermarionation - a puppetry technique that used fine wires and electronics to move the puppets’ lips. John, Virgil, Scott, Gordon and Alan Tracy are brothers who combat danger using their numerous spacecrafts, working for International Rescue, helmed by their father Jeff. Brains, Lady Penelope, Parker, Kyrano and Tin-Tin ably assist the family on their missions. Four episodes from the show are: “Trapped in the sky”: Arch-enemy The Hood places an explosive device aboard an aircraft in order to photograph Thunderbirds craft. “Pit of peril”: A revolutionary mobile unit used by the Army goes haywire and the ingenious Brains battles to right the vehicle and save the lives of those on board. “City of fire”: When a fire breaks out in a space age shopping mall, Scott and Virgil try to save one trapped family from certain death. “Sun probe”: A research ship loses its way and is headed for a collision course with the sun. Alan and Scott are called upon to right its trajectory, in a daring rescue mission. Wonderfully inventive television, suitable for children.

results.title: Blade II
results.creator_credit: Guillermo del Toro, Patrick Palmer, Peter Frankfurt, Wesley Snipes and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Based on Marvel Comics more dark super hero franchise, “Blade II” chronicles the adventures of a half human, half vampire (Wesley Snipes) who diligently protects humans from the seething vampire underworld. Mexican horror director Guillermo del Toro (The Devil’s backbone, Cronos) has fashioned a faithful sequel which delves deeper into the vampire mythology set up in the first film while maintaining the series penchant for blood soaked martial arts action. Set in Prague (its gothic buildings and ancient cobblestoned streets make this a fitting location for a vampire movie), “Blade II“‘s action takes off when a new breed of vampires are discovered, the Deadly Reapers. These nasty nightcrawlers not only feed on humans but are not impartial to vampire blood as well. This causes the worried vampire fraternity (known as the Shadow Council) to form an uneasy alliance with arch-enemy Blade and his gruff side-kick Whistler (Kris Kristofferson). Together they must hunt down and destroy the rapidly spreading reapers before they eliminate all the vampires and take over the human race. Cast includes: Luke Goss, Ron Perlman, Leonor Varela, Norman Reedus.

results.title: The Importance of being earnest [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Asquith, Teddy Baird, Javelin, Rank Film Productions and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Film adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s brilliant play “The Importance of being earnest” (1895), adapted and directed for the screen by Anthony Asquith, is probably the best-known comedy of manners in the world. Jack Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff are friends, both bachelors operating in English society hoping to find love in a proper match. Each man has spun lies about a fake identity in order to achieve romance with Gwendolyn Fairfax and Cecily Cardew, respectively. When the two couples meet up at Cecily’s place of residence, their lies unfurl and the true selves of both are revealed. Wilde’s last play is a satire on English society and manners, wonderfully sending up the portentousness and pomposity of the upper classes. Two particularly memorable characters are the boorish snob Lady Bracknell and the dithering governess Miss Prism (the latter played with import here by Margaret Rutherford). Asquith never quite transcends the script’s theatrical origins, but does successfully recreate the cadence and spirit of Wilde’s sardonic, barbed wit.

results.title: Promises
results.creator_credit: B.Z. Goldberg, Justine Shapiro and Promises Film Project
results.brief_description: Promises was filmed over a period of four years, from 1997 to 2000, a time where there seemed to be a degree of relative calm in Israel and the Palestinian Territories (following on from the Oslo Accords). Perceiving the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict through the eyes of seven children, this film is an astoundingly compassionate and illuminating document about the human cost of war. Four of the children are Jewish and live in the city. Three of the children are Arab and have been born and raised in refugee camps in the Occupied Territories on the West Bank. Though divided by a journey of less than twenty minutes, it is as if they live in completely different worlds. By allowing the harsh realities of terrorism and the Intifada, of occupation and resistance, to be filtered through the experience of the children, “Promises” builds a compelling argument for multicultural and religious tolerance. The film climaxes with a meeting of the Palestinian and Israeli children which articulates the profound desire for peace on both sides. However, given the complexity of the politics of the conflict, “Promises” refuses to pretend that there are simple or straightforward answers to the co-existence of the two peoples. A coda which sees the filmmakers return to Jerusalem finds the children older, more cynical, and already involved in the hatred that arises from war: it is as if the failures of the peace negotiations are mirrored in the daily lives of the children themselves. “Promises” was nominated for an Academy Award for best feature documentary and it is a testament to the ethical and humanitarian commitments of its directors, Shapiro and Goldberg, that it allows for both emotional and intellectual engagement by the viewer, an engagement that never strikes one as manipulative. There is no false politicised “objectivity” assumed in “Promises” by the directors. Part of the film’s power arises from Goldberg and Shapiro desiring to assist the children on both sides of the conflict. It is their compassionate involvement that gives the film its grand tragic force. The video comes with explanatory notes and a study guide.

results.title: Thunderball (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Kevin McClory, Danjaq, Eon Productions and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: Thunderball is the fourth Bond film with Sean Connery playing British secret service agent 007, pitting his stylish form against the espionage organisation SPECTRE (Special Executive for Counter-Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion), with Emilio Largo at the helm. SPECTRE plans to hijack a nuclear bomb, plant it under the sea, and then hold the world for ransom. Set in the Bahamas, “Thunderball” provides plenty of lush scenery with spectacular beaches, sprawling mansions and beautiful women in bathing costumes. The under water setting allows for some spectacular ideas and elaborate set pieces. Typical Bond touches include a myriad of one liners and nubile lady friends including a masseuse; Largo’s mistress; a British spy; and an enemy agent. Highlights include a Mardi Gras sequence with James evading capture due to a frenetic, chaotic moment. Other fine moments are the irascible Q displaying Bond’s latest gadgets whilst whingeing about being dragged to the Bahamas in order to do so. Re-made in 1993 as “Never say never again.”

results.title: The Man with the golden gun (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Guy Hamilton, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and Danjaq
results.brief_description: Born in a circus, Francisco Scaramanga (Christopher Lee) is a killer for hire, an ex KGB assassin and the man with the golden gun. When MI5 receives a signature Scaramanga bullet with 007 on it, Bond (Roger Moore) is sent on an undercover mission to locate the man with a million dollar fee. After retrieving a gold bullet from the midriff of an Israeli belly dancer, Bond leaves for the exotic city of Macau where he makes contact with Portuguese weapons expert, Lazar. An assassination attempt reveals that the real target was a missing energy expert who created the Solex Agitator - an energy converter capable of harnessing the sun’s radiation. Ably assisted by Goodnight (Britt Ekland), Bond also finds time to woo Scaramanga’s mistress, Andrea Anders (Maud Adams, who would later appear with Roger Moore in Octopussy). Highlights include James taking on sumo wrestlers and karate experts, a lengthy boat and car chase and impressive use of a fake nipple. The film culminates in a chamber-of-horrors showdown, with red-lit, mirrors and optical illusions and a voiceover by Scaramanga’s short statured sidekick, Nick Nack (Fantasy Islands Herve Villechaiz). Shot across various exotic locations, the film was criticized for 007s uncharacteristic misogyny against his female counterparts.

results.title: Diamonds are forever (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Guy Hamilton, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman, United Artists Corporation and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: After bowing out in “You only live twice”, Sean Connery reprised his role as James Bond in “Diamonds are forever”, his second last outing as British Secret Service agent 007. From the diamond mines of South Africa, numerous caches of goods are going missing, making authorities fear that the market is in danger of being flooded. Bond is assigned to unravel the identity of the mystery stockpiler by going undercover as Peter Franks, a crook who is a part of a smuggling ring. A typically labyrinthine plot sends Bond to Amsterdam and then Las Vegas, chasing the recipient of a large diamond delivery whilst enjoying the charms of fellow smuggler Tiffany Case (Jill St John). Bond’s nemesis, Ernst Stavros Blofeld, returns planning to use the diamonds in a satellite that will allow him to hold the world for ransom. Bond survives his own cremation as well as encounters with memorable killers Mr Wint and Mr Kidd, a diabolical pair of lovers with a deadpan sense of humour, and two lethal martial arts gymnasts, Bambi and Thumper, who give Bond a going over. Thrills include a car chase in Las Vegas with numerous cops in pursuit and a ride in a moon buggy through the Nevada desert.

results.title: Ordinary decent criminal
results.creator_credit: Thaddeus O'Sullivan, Jonathan Cavendish, ICON and Little Bird
results.brief_description: Kevin Spacey plays Michael Lynch, a suave and cocky Irish gangster who has something of a reputation with ordinary folk as a local hero. With a loyal gang and always two steps ahead of the law, Michael plans numerous heists, such as a daylight robbery of a precious Caravaggio, along with pulling ordinary bank jobs and robbing his own dole office. Michael’s unusual home life consists of two partners, who are sisters, and numerous children, a delightful arrangement for one and all. Enraged by Michael’s elusiveness and brazen disregard for authority, the police place him and his lot under unyielding surveillance, but the scallywag gives them the slip every time. “Ordinary decent criminal” is a reworking of the true to life Martin Cahill story as told in “The General” (John Boorman, 1998), a far more cynical film about crime. O’Sullivan’s film has a certain incongruity in tone - it is mostly jaunty with a hip soundtrack, but occasionally cuts to violent encounters. Spacey depicts Lynch as a clever, vain and loveable rouge with a wry smile, but a thief and swindler at heart.

results.title: Two women = Do zan [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Arman Film and Arta Film
results.brief_description: Two women, Fereshteh (Niki Karimi) and Roya (Marila Zare’i) become friends while studying at Tehran University. There’s a cloud of doubt over whether the university will stay open however, there’s rioting, and Fereshteh fears her future plans to become educated and enlightened will not eventuate. One day she is approached by a girl at university who wants to introduce her to Ahmad, a potential husband, she’s also being harassed by a man who follows her around campus and insists he is in love with her. One day the man sees her with her cousin and, believing him to be her lover, throws acid on him. Fereshteh is unfairly blamed for the incident and her father demands she leave university and return home. An unfortunate accident removes her harasser when he is sent to jail, but Fereshteh is held to blame also and is bailed out by Ahmad, her life and family honour indebted to him due to his financial assistance. Milani’s fifth film is an accomplished piece about a woman stifled in her attempt at liberation by a trinity involving her father, her husband, and a stranger.

results.title: The Hidden half = Nimeh-ye penhan [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tahmineh Milani, Mohammad Nikbin, Arta Film and Iranian Film Society
results.brief_description: The dutiful wife of an Iranian judge uses her husband’s impending case of a woman facing execution for an unspecified crime to reveal the truth of her past revolutionary activities and to illustrate that the stories of people must be heard before passing judgement. Using the device of a diary and an extended flashback, Fereshteh (Niki Karima, Best Actress, Cairo International Film Festival) explains how her life changed drastically when she went to university, joined the Communist party, then fell in love with a married man. Feminist director Tahmineh Milani was imprisoned by the Islamic Revolutionary Court following the film’s release and is on parole; the film was also pulled from Tehran screens after a month but later returned. Melodramatic at times, the film’s history overshadows its content yet still manages to convey the oppression of Iranian women under an Islamic regime in pre and post revolutionary Iran. In Farsi with English subtitles. Please note: the white subtitles are sometimes hard to read on screen.
